review.title: NeuroSVM: A Graphical User Interface for Identification of Liver Patients
review.abstract: Diagnosis of liver infection at preliminary stage is important for better treatment. In todays scenario devices like sensors are used for detection of infections. Accurate classification techniques are required for automatic identification of disease samples. In this context, this study utilizes data mining approaches for classification of liver patients from healthy individuals. Four algorithms (Naive Bayes, Bagging, Random forest and SVM) were implemented for classification using R platform. Further to improve the accuracy of classification a hybrid NeuroSVM model was developed using SVM and feed-forward artificial neural network (ANN). The hybrid model was tested for its performance using statistical parameters like root mean square error (RMSE) and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE). The model resulted in a prediction accuracy of 98.83%. The results suggested that development of hybrid model improved the accuracy of prediction. To serve the medicinal community for prediction of liver disease among patients, a graphical user interface (GUI) has been developed using R. The GUI is deployed as a package in local repository of R platform for users to perform prediction.

sections.heading: 3.1. Data Collection
sections.text: The Indian Liver Patient Dataset (ILPD) was selected for this study from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, a sample of the entire Indian population from the Andhra Pradesh region. The dataset included 583 cases based on ten different biological parameters. The class value was given either yes (416 cases) or no (167 cases) based on these parameters to represent the liver infection.

sections.heading: 3.2. Pre-processing and Feature selection
sections.text: The missing values, together with their instances, were replaced by a zero value, followed by a feature selection to identify relevant attributes for classification. The feature selection was done using both filter and winding methods. First, the attributes with a correlation of more than 70% were removed from the data set by correlation analysis, followed by the feature selection using the library "Boruta" in R. The algorithm was implemented on the basis of random forests to estimate the importance of different features in a data set [17].

sections.heading: 3.3. Randomization and splitting of dataset
sections.text: First, the data set was randomized to obtain any permutated sample, then the data set was divided into training sets (70% of the data set) and test sets (30%), the training set comprised 389 instances and the test set comprised the remaining 194 instances.

sections.heading: 3.4. Classification algorithms
sections.text: The algorithm is based on the Bayes Conditional Probability Theorem. The obtained bootstrap sample is equipped with models that use the selection scheme for classification. The algorithm is considered an average scheme for random decision trees. Breiman developed the algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.5. Development of hybrid model
sections.text: The hybrid model was developed to further increase the accuracy of prediction of liver disease. SVM classification was better than other algorithms. SVM was implemented in the hybrid model in conjunction with an artificial neural network. A neural feed network was fed the SVM classifier. The hybrid neuroSVM predictor was implemented in R with the "Neuralnet" package [22]. The statistical significance of the hybrid model was evaluated on the basis of the root mean square (RMSE) and the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE).

sections.heading: 3.6. Deployment of hybrid model as GUI in R
sections.text: The hybrid model was implemented as a user-friendly GUI in R to facilitate the prediction of liver disease in a patient. It was developed using "gWidgets," "RGtk2" and "tcltk2" libraries in R [23, 24 and 25] and can be used as a screening tool for predicting liver disease.4. Results and discussion

sections.heading: 4.2. Feature Selection
sections.text: The ten attributes available in the ILPD dataset cannot be used to develop a precise classification model; only the relevant attributes need to be selected; the attributes in the dataset have been subjected to correlation analysis to remove redundant attributes; the correlated attributes have also been subjected to feature selection using the "Boruta" package in R. sections.heading: 4.3. Application of classification algorithms
sections.text: Four algorithms were implemented to classify the Indian Liver Patients Data Set: Naïve Bayes, Bagging, Random Forest and SVM. Models were generated for the training set and evaluated on the test set. Based on the accuracy of the prediction, it was determined that SVM reached an accuracy of 76.22%. The prediction result from SVM was used to develop a hybrid model.

sections.heading: 4.4. Development of hybrid model
sections.text: The hybrid model for the assessment of liver disease was created with the help of neural networks. SVM prediction results were fed into an artificial neural feed network consisting of 2 input layers, 5 hidden layers and an output layer. Neural networks were inspired by neurons in the brain. The network is represented as a weighted graph with nodes and edges. The input function is represented by xj in such a way that j = 1, 2.... n. The output function is calculated according to the formula: nj uwjxjy 1 equation (1) Here y = output function wj = weights for input j xj = input function u = threshold function θ = unit-step function The algorithm calculates output class and network for input evaluated on the basis of the allocated weights. The algorithm was implemented with the help of the "neural net package" in R. The hybrid model was calculated with better performance compared to the recorder.

sections.heading: 4.5. Deployment of GUI in R
sections.text: The hybrid NeuroSVM model is used as a GUI in R with the packages "gWidgets," "RGtk2" and "tcltk." The biological properties of the patients are used as input for the prediction of liver diseases. Attributes are predicted by the SVM model. Followed by the implementation of a feed forward hybrid NeuroSVM model for predicting liver patients. The package "NeuroSVM" is installed locally in the machine for predicting liver diseases. Users can use the GUI by installing the package in R in their local machines. This application can be used by physicians and medical professionals to access the likelihood of liver infection in a patient for the first screening.
